summary.long: Song Of Solomon is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The Song of Songs, which is Solomon’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth!
For your love is better than wine;
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I am black and beautiful,
    O daughters of Jerusalem,
like the tents of Kedar,
    like the curtains of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not gaze at me because I am dark,
    because the sun has gazed on me.
My mother’s sons were angry with me;
    they made me keeper of the vineyards,
    but my own vineyard I have not kept!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tell me, you whom my soul loves,
    where you pasture your flock,
    where you make it lie down at noon,
for why should I be like one who is veiled
    beside the flocks of your companions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you do not know,
    O fairest among women,
follow the tracks of the flock
    and pasture your kids
    beside the shepherds’ tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I compare you, my love,
    to a mare among Pharaoh’s chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your cheeks are comely with ornaments,
    your neck with strings of jewels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We will make you ornaments of gold,
    studded with silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While the king was on his couch,
    my nard gave forth its fragrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is to me a bag of myrrh
    that lies between my breasts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms
    in the vineyards of En-gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
the beams of our house are cedar;
    our rafters are pine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am a rose of Sharon,
    a lily of the valleys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a lily among brambles,
    so is my love among maidens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As an apple tree among the trees of the wood,
    so is my beloved among young men.
With great delight I sat in his shadow,
    and his fruit was sweet to my taste.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brought me to the banqueting house,
    and his intention toward me was love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sustain me with raisins,
    refresh me with apples,
    for I am faint with love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O that his left hand were under my head
    and that his right hand embraced me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles or the wild does:
do not stir up or awaken love
    until it is ready!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The voice of my beloved!
    Look, he comes,
leaping upon the mountains,
    bounding over the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is like a gazelle
    or a young stag.
Look, there he stands
    behind our wall,
gazing in at the windows,
    looking through the lattice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved speaks and says to me:
“Arise, my love, my fair one,
    and come away,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for now the winter is past,
    the rain is over and gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The flowers appear on the earth;
    the time of singing has come,
and the voice of the turtledove
    is heard in our land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fig tree puts forth its figs,
    and the vines are in blossom;
    they give forth fragrance.
Arise, my love, my fair one,
    and come away.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Catch us the foxes,
    the little foxes,
that ruin the vineyards—
    for our vineyards are in blossom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is mine, and I am his;
    he pastures his flock among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Until the day breathes
    and the shadows flee,
turn, my beloved, be like a gazelle
    or a young stag on the cleft mountains.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“I will rise now and go about the city,
    in the streets and in the squares;
I will seek him whom my soul loves.”
    I sought him but found him not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sentinels found me,
    as they went about in the city.
“Have you seen him whom my soul loves?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Scarcely had I passed them,
    when I found him whom my soul loves.
I held him and would not let him go
    until I brought him into my mother’s house
    and into the chamber of her that conceived me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles or the wild does:
do not stir up or awaken love
    until it is ready!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is that coming up from the wilderness
    like a column of smoke,
perfumed with myrrh and frankincense,
    with all the fragrant powders of the merchant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, it is the litter of Solomon!
Around it are sixty mighty men
    of the mighty men of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
all equipped with swords
    and expert in war,
each with his sword at his thigh
    because of alarms by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
King Solomon made himself a palanquin
    from the wood of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made its posts of silver,
    its back of gold, its seat of purple;
its interior was inlaid with stone.
    Daughters of Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
come out and look
    at King Solomon,
at the crown with which his mother crowned him
    on the day of his wedding,
    on the day of the gladness of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful you are, my love,
    how very beautiful!
Your eyes are doves
    behind your veil.
Your hair is like a flock of goats,
    moving down the slopes of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your teeth are like a flock of shorn ewes
    that have come up from the washing,
all of which bear twins,
    and not one among them is bereaved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your lips are like a crimson thread,
    and your mouth is lovely.
Your cheeks are like halves of a pomegranate
    behind your veil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your neck is like the tower of David,
    built in courses;
on it hang a thousand bucklers,
    all of them shields of warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
    twins of a gazelle,
    that feed among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Until the day breathes
    and the shadows flee,
I will hasten to the mountain of myrrh
    and the hill of frankincense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are altogether beautiful, my love;
    there is no flaw in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
How sweet is your love, my sister, my bride!
    How much better is your love than wine
    and the fragrance of your oils than any spice!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
A garden locked is my sister, my bride,
    a garden locked, a fountain sealed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your channel is an orchard of pomegranates
    with all choicest fruits,
    henna with nard,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
nard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon,
    with all trees of frankincense,
myrrh and aloes,
    with all chief spices—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a garden fountain, a well of living water,
    and flowing streams from Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Awake, O north wind,
    and come, O south wind!
Blow upon my garden
    that its fragrance may be wafted abroad.
Let my beloved come to his garden
    that he may eat its choicest fruits.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I was sleeping, but my heart was awake.
The sound of my beloved knocking!
“Open to me, my sister, my love,
    my dove, my perfect one,
for my head is wet with dew,
    my locks with the drops of the night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved thrust his hand into the opening,
    and my inmost being yearned for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I arose to open to my beloved,
    and my hands dripped with myrrh,
my fingers with liquid myrrh,
    upon the handles of the bolt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I opened to my beloved,
    but my beloved had turned away and was gone.
My soul failed me when he spoke.
I sought him but did not find him;
    I called him, but he gave no answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    if you find my beloved,
tell him this:
    I am faint with love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is your beloved more than another beloved,
    O fairest among women?
What is your beloved more than another beloved,
    that you thus charge us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is all radiant and ruddy,
    distinguished among ten thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
His eyes are like doves
    beside springs of water,
bathed in milk,
    fitly set.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His cheeks are like beds of spices,
    yielding fragrance.
His lips are lilies,
    dripping liquid myrrh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His arms are rounded gold,
    set with jewels.
His body is an ivory panel,
    decorated with sapphires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His legs are alabaster columns,
    set upon bases of gold.
His appearance is like Lebanon,
    choice as the cedars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His speech is most sweet,
    and he is altogether desirable.
This is my beloved, and this is my friend,
    O daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where has your beloved gone,
    O fairest among women?
Which way has your beloved turned
    that we may seek him with you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved has gone down to his garden,
    to the beds of spices,
to pasture his flock in the gardens
    and to gather lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine;
    he pastures his flock among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are beautiful as Tirzah, my love,
    comely as Jerusalem,
    terrible as an army with banners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn away your eyes from me,
    for they overwhelm me!
Your hair is like a flock of goats,
    moving down the slopes of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your teeth are like a flock of ewes
    that have come up from the washing;
all of them bear twins,
    and not one among them is bereaved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your cheeks are like halves of a pomegranate
    behind your veil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are sixty queens and eighty concubines
    and maidens without number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My dove, my perfect one, is the only one,
    the darling of her mother,
    flawless to her who bore her.
The maidens saw her and called her happy;
    the queens and concubines praised her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who is this that looks forth like the dawn,
    fair as the moon, bright as the sun,
    terrible as an army with banners?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I went down to the nut orchard
    to look at the blossoms of the valley,
to see whether the vines had budded,
    whether the pomegranates were in bloom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Before I was aware, my desire set me
    in a chariot beside my prince.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Return, return, O Shulammite!
    Return, return, that we may look upon you.
Why should you look upon the Shulammite,
    as upon a dance before two armies?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How graceful are your feet in sandals,
    O queenly maiden!
Your rounded thighs are like jewels,
    the work of a master hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your navel is a rounded bowl;
    may it never lack mixed wine.
Your belly is a heap of wheat,
    encircled with lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
    twins of a gazelle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your neck is like an ivory tower.
Your eyes are pools in Heshbon,
    by the gate of Bath-rabbim.
Your nose is like a tower of Lebanon,
    overlooking Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
How fair and pleasant you are,
    O loved one, delectable maiden!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are stately as a palm tree,
    and your breasts are like its clusters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I said, “I will climb the palm tree
    and lay hold of its branches.”
O may your breasts be like clusters of the vine,
    and the scent of your breath like apples,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and your kisses like the best wine
    that goes down smoothly,
    gliding over lips and teeth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am my beloved’s,
    and his desire is for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The mandrakes give forth fragrance,
    and over our doors are all choice fruits,
new as well as old,
    which I have laid up for you, O my beloved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O that you were like a brother to me,
    who nursed at my mother’s breast!
If I met you outside, I would kiss you,
    and no one would despise me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would lead you and bring you
    into my mother’s house
    and into the chamber of the one who bore me.
I would give you spiced wine to drink,
    from the juice of my pomegranates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O that his left hand were under my head
    and that his right hand embraced me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    do not stir up or awaken love
    until it is ready!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is that coming up from the wilderness,
    leaning upon her beloved?
Under the apple tree I awakened you.
There your mother was in labor with you;
    there she who bore you was in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Set me as a seal upon your heart,
    as a seal upon your arm,
for love is strong as death,
    passion fierce as the grave.
Its flashes are flashes of fire,
    a raging flame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Many waters cannot quench love,
    neither can floods drown it.
If one offered for love
    all the wealth of one’s house,
    it would be utterly scorned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have a little sister,
    and she has no breasts.
What shall we do for our sister,
    on the day when she is spoken for?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If she is a wall,
    we will build upon her a battlement of silver,
but if she is a door,
    we will enclose her with boards of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was a wall,
    and my breasts were like towers;
then I was in his eyes
    as one who brings peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Make haste, my beloved,
    and be like a gazelle
or a young stag
    upon the mountains of spices!
verses.speaker: Narrator
